q_01.text: Do you currently plan on returning research costs to clients once the FCA and the EU implement their research rebundling recommendations?

a.text: Yes

b.text: No

q_02.text: You answered no. What is the main reason why?

a.text: Need to see regulatory alignment across the UK and the EU first which is not a given

b.text: There is no appetite to approach clients to reintroduce these costs

c.text: We are comfortable with our existing research valuation and funding structure

d.text: It will depend on the detail of the FCA’s detailed rules and the implications on operational complexity and cost

q_03.text: What is the most significant factor that would make it possible to implement?

a.text: A prolonged bull market

b.text: a narrative in the media and other channels that underlines how research costs are small compared to their positive effect on performance

c.text: A large global asset manager doing it first, making it easier to follow suit

d.text: Clear, specific guidelines from the FCA/EU Listing Act covering disclosure that are not open to interpretation

q_04.text: You answered yes. What is the main reason you think it is achievable?

a.text: End investors will understand that research costs are low in comparison to the impact more optionality on research payments will have on performance

b.text: A large asset manager will eventually go first and remove any stigma for others

c.text: End investors are not focused on research costs

d.text: End investors are more focused on transparency, so if the correct disclosures exist they will accept the return of these charges

q_05.text: In a scenario where you did return research costs to end investor clients, what would be the likely effect to your budgeting?

a.text: Our research budget would go up 20%+

b.text: Our research budget would go up 10%+

c.text: Our research budget would stabilise whereas it may have decreased otherwise

q_06.text: In a scenario where you did return research costs to end investor clients, what do you think would be the effect on research supply?

a.text: Research on SMEs would increase

b.text: High quality, differentiated research would increase

c.text: More budget would be available for independent research providers

d.text: More budget would be available to niche brokers

e.text: More budget would be available to the bulge bracket firms

q_07.text: In the final FCA/EU Listing Act rules what would you most like to see?

a.text: Clear and definitive guidance on how much disclosure on research payments to clients would be required

b.text: Freedom to pay for corporate access with commissions

c.text: Clear stipulation that the sell side cannot force bundled payments

d.text: Flexibility to pay for research in whichever way is appropriate

e.text: freedom to set up traditional CSA programmes in the name of the broker, rather than using RPA structures which would be in the asset manager’s name
